title: Job Interviews Don’t Work

title: Why You Feel At Home In A Crisis
description: When disaster strikes, people come together. During the worst times of our lives, we can end up experiencing the best mental health and relationships with others. Here’s why that happens and how we can bring the lessons we learn with us once things get better.

title: Stop Preparing For The Last Disaster
description: When something goes wrong, we often strive to be better prepared if the same thing happens again. But the same disasters tend not to happen twice in a row. A more effective approach is simply to prepare to be surprised by life, instead of expecting the past to repeat itself.

title: Coordination Problems: What It Takes to Change the World
description: The key to major changes on a societal level is getting enough people to alter their behavior at the same time. It’s not enough for isolated individuals to act. Here’s what we can learn from coordination games in game theory about what it takes to solve some of the biggest problems we face.

title: The Art of Being Alone
description: Loneliness has more to do with our perceptions than how much company we have. It’s just as possible to be painfully lonely surrounded by people as it is to be content with little social contact. Some people need extended periods of time alone to recharge, others would rather give themselves electric shocks than spend a few minutes with their thoughts. Here’s how we can change our perceptions by making and experiencing art.

title: When Safety Proves Dangerous
description: Not everything we do with the aim of making ourselves safer has that effect. Sometimes, knowing there are measures in place to protect us from harm can lead us to take greater risks and cancel out the benefits. This is known as risk compensation. Understanding how it affects our behavior can help us make the best possible decisions in an uncertain world.

title: Rethinking Fear

title: Bad Arguments and How to Avoid Them

title: Insensitivity To Base Rates: An Introduction
description: In statistics, a base rate refers to the percentage of a population (e.g. grasshoppers, people who live in New York, newborn babies) which have a characteristic. Given a random individual and no additional information, the base rate tells us the likelihood of them exhibiting that characteristic. For instance, around 10% of people are left-handed. If you selected a random person and had no information related to their handedness, you could safely guess there to be a 1 in 10 chance of them being left-handed.

title: Mental Model: Prisoners’ Dilemma
description: The prisoners’ dilemma is the best known strategy game in social science. The game shows why two entities might not cooperate even when it appears in their best (rational) interest to do so. What is rational for the individual in certain circumstances is not rational for the group — that is, pursuing a strategy that is rational for you leads to a worse outcome.

title: The Principles of Comparative Advantage: Why Tiger Woods Shouldn’t Mow Your Lawn

It also explains why Tiger Woods shouldn’t mow your lawn.
